stream_context.summary: Asset-import and engine-tuning session.  Kaze brings the new temple/disco section of “Return to Yoshi’s Island” up to date: adds updated doors, Poochie, Shy Guys, spinning apple collectible, and finishes the giant egg chase.  Major focus on making Mario’s collision deterministic and squeezing everything into N64 RAM/ROM limits.
level: Basement disco/temple area of the Poochie level

development_findings.summary: Implemented rubber-banding logic for the giant Yoshi egg chase so the egg speeds up as the player gets ahead.
Finished a major collision rewrite: Mario now always sticks to walkable slopes, eliminating the quarter-frame randomness in vanilla SM64.
development_findings.quote: I want to remove quarter frame precision from the player's mind.

development_findings.summary: Engine upgrade phase is almost complete; legacy geometry is breaking but future bugs should slow down once upgrades stop.
Overworld progress was restored after being accidentally skipped; work will return there once the current level is done.
Imported Biobak’s new Pucci model (fewer materials, updated colors) with only minor weighting and mirror issues to fix.
Imported temple gates and re-worked door animation (side-opening, correct culling radius, synced pair).

Added spinning apple collectible.  To keep vertex colors yet add shading, Kaze wrote per-frame CPU code that rotates the light vector and injects it into shade color, creating smooth lighting on hardware.
development_findings.quote: All this just to get some shadows on the stupid apple.

development_findings.summary: Flower Shy Guy asset is in; will need new animations because the rig changed.
Fixed several collision bugs caused by engine changes (e.g., clipping through blocks when holding specific inputs).
RAM almost overflowed; Kaze moved small assets to the emergency pool, regaining space.  ROM now ~60 MB of 64 MB; plans to delete unused vanilla assets.
Considering split-screen multiplayer (two stacked viewports) but notes extra framebuffer memory cost.
Camera auto-rotation will be disabled in the tight corridor before Pucci to reduce disorientation.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design philosophy: randomness in core movement is unacceptable; players shouldn’t need to know about sub-frame mechanics.
context_findings.quote: There never should be any randomness in Mario's movement.

context_findings.summary: Approach to tools: learn hotkeys first, then create – ‘learn your tools, then you get to have fun.’
Personal life bits: wife Zeina jokingly shaved his hair; baby now says “baa baa baa”; excited about a robotic lawn-mower he calls a pet.
Merch integration with TeePublic is delayed; mild frustration at lost sales.
Mentions Nintendo’s takedown of his Zelda hack ‘The Missing Link’ and planning a follow-up video.
Streams focus on visible asset work; bug-fixing happens off-stream, impacting his work–life balance.

biobak.summary: Supplied updated assets: temple doors, disco lighting egg gate, Poochie overhaul, apple, new Shy Guys, crown plant, etc.
Actively consulted in chat about shaders, lighting direction, and memory savings.

zeina.summary: Created earlier versions of the Flower Shy Guy; her legacy rig still visible in asset discussion.
Provided a new thumbnail mock-up for Kaze’s upcoming F3 video.

key_stories.title: Killing Quarter-Frame Randomness
key_stories.summary: Vanilla SM64 randomly decides whether Mario sticks to certain slopes.  Kaze found this unacceptable and rewrote the collision step so Mario always stays on walkable surfaces.
key_stories.challenge: Random, frame-dependent behavior on slopes undermined player trust.
key_stories.process: Replaced sub-frame step checks with near-continuous collision, tested edge-cases, demonstrated during stream.
key_stories.outcome: Consistent slope behavior; Kaze proud, declares engine upgrade nearly done.
key_stories.key_quote: I feel like the player should never think about their quarter frames when they play my game.

key_stories.title: Lighting the Apple
key_stories.summary: Biobak’s spinning apple needed both vertex colors and dynamic shading.  The N64 combiner limits forced a creative solution.
key_stories.challenge: Vertex colors killed normal shading, making the spin look flat.
key_stories.process: Kaze wrote CPU code that calculates per-vertex shade each frame, rotates the light vector with the apple, and injects it into shade alpha.
key_stories.outcome: Apple now spins with convincing highlights without extra textures.
key_stories.key_quote: All this just to get some shadows on the stupid apple.

key_stories.title: Running Out of Memory
key_stories.summary: While importing new assets the game hit RAM limits and nearly exceeded the 64 MB ROM ceiling.
key_stories.challenge: Compilation failed from ‘out of memory’ warnings during asset import.
key_stories.process: Identified which models could live in the emergency pool; re-allocated small data; noted plan to delete unused vanilla assets.
key_stories.outcome: Game now fits again (RAM safe, ROM at 60 MB); highlights looming technical constraint.
key_stories.key_quote: We have four more megabytes – reduce the size, remove the stuff we don't use.
